Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Processes and Patterns in The North American Monsoon Macrosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on studying the processes in the earth's climate system that control the spatial coverage and year-to-year variation in the North American Monsoon System, which supports ecological and human systems from central Mexico through the southwestern United States. The study will use advanced computer models that combine weather forecasting with biological processes associated with the plants on the ground to determine how the highly variable monsoon rains control the spread of invasive grasses, including cheat grass and buffel grass, and the how the spread of these invasive grasses may, in turn, influence seasonal weather patterns and the monsoon system itself. Other aspects include the analysis of tree rings from across the southwest that will reveal historical patterns in the magnitude and distribution of the monsoons and also can be used to validate model predictions. The study will also explore how low elevation dry grasslands and high elevation forests compare with regard to cycles of wildfires. Summer rains are likely to influence the spread of fires from grasslands to forests and this study will help explain how this connection is influenced by variability in the monsoon rains. Finally, an effort will made to extend understanding of what controls monsoon rains to include natural cycles in climate, such as those associated with the two-to-seven year El Nino cycle and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, both of which affect surface temperatures of the Pacific Ocean. This is a search for the ultimate causes of the coupling between monsoon rains and the ecological systems in the region. For example, a main objective will be to explore the nature of the climate and ecological forces that define the spatial extent of the monsoon system, and the ocean processes and cycles that define its magnitude and long-term variation. The participants in this large and integrated project include ecologists and climate scientists working together, from both the U.S. and Mexico.

This project will have broader impacts to science and society in several ways. Six post-doctoral students and seven graduate students will be trained. A Discovery Fellows program will be created through the Laboratory of Tree Ring Research that will hire six school teachers, including some from the Navajo Nation, who will be involved in assembling a tree ring archive for the southwest. A process will be established to develop a new regional land surface computer model that will be administered by the National Center for Atmospheric Research and made widely available for use. A bi-national collaboration with Mexico will be started that will include extended visits each year with scientists and graduate students. Finally, a display will be created that describes the relevance of summer monsoons to Native American groups and contemporary societies; it will be housed and shown at the Biosphere 2 Center in Tucson, which hosts about 75,000 visitors each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New computer models were developed and advanced stable isotope techniques were used to assess how ecosystems in the semi-arid southwestern US respond to variability in the summer monsoon rains that occur every year and are susceptible to periodic changes in the climate system, such as cycles in ocean sea-surface temperatures and systematic human-caused forcing of atmospheric green-house gas concentrations. The research was designed to take on a new scale of ecological analysis – the regional scale that considers numerous neighboring ecosystems as a novel ecological unit – the macrosystem. The North American Monsoon (NAM) climate system organizes ecosystems in the southwestern US into a cohesive macrosystem controlled by infrequent summer pulses of moisture that arrive to this otherwise hot, dry region. The challenges associated with studying ecological interactions in this macrosystem are to develop research at the smaller spatial and temporal scales that define the short, intense monsoon storms, yet also cover the larger scales required to discern average trends that occur across the entire macrosystem domain. In this project, these challenges were addressed and mitigated by: (1) developing a new computer modeling framework that allowed us to shift from the 35-km and 1-day scales of earlier studies, to a new framework with 1-km spatial and 1-hour scales; and (2) developing a means of making observations of vegetation-atmosphere interactions across the decadal-to-centennial scales using tree rings.

Two major breakthroughs were realized in the area of computer modeling. First, we developed a new land surface model, known as Noah-MP for Micro Physics, and modified the atmospheric physics algorithms of a commonly-used regional climate model, known as WRF for Weather Research and Forecast, to produce a composite model capable of making predictions of vegetation-atmosphere interactions at much smaller scales. This new model included greater detail on plant traits and soil properties, and more accurate algorithms to describe how solar energy moves through complex plant canopies. Second, we developed a new modeling framework for tracing water molecules as they evaporate from vegetated surfaces, are transported across the landscape, and precipitate as rain in distant parts of the macrosystem. Both of these models were supported by new analyses of how to use images produced from satellite remote sensing to best characterize vegetation within the macrosystem domain. Together, these studies were used to produce scientific papers, which provided the following conclusions: (1) inclusion of our new algorithms describing the microphysics processes of the land surface model has eliminated several model biases that led to inaccuracies in describing summer monsoon rain patterns in the southwestern US, (2) prediction that changes in sea surface temperature in the northeastern tropical Pacific and Gulf of California, in particular, will have a positive and significant influence on the amount of summer monsoon moisture delivered to the macrosystem, (3) discovery that the recycling of terrestrial soil moisture is as important a driving force for northward expansion of the monsoon system as the low-level atmospheric jet previously considered as the primary mechanism delivering moisture to the macrosystem, and (4) discovery of a recent trend from satellite vegetation data that an earlier greening associated with monsoon activity occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental Mountains of Mexico, where the monsoon is initiated each year.

Several breakthroughs were achieved using observations of tree rings. One of the most important that montane pine forests in the southern part of the macrosystem, where monsoon activity is greatest, receive enough summer moisture to render them 'insensitive' in their growth to year-to-year variability in monsoon magnitude. In other words, future shifts in the interannual variation of summer climate in this part of the macrosystem will have less effect on forests in the southern part of the macrosystem than regions near the northern boundary of the macrosystem in southern Utah and northern Arizona. A second major discovery was the recognition that the monsoon climate system alters atmospheric humidity as a primary influence on forest tree growth and atmospheric carbon dioxide uptake. This has led to a new hypothesis that atmospheric humidity is equal to, or greater than, soil moisture in its importance as a climate control over regional forest carbon gain. Using tree-ring fire scars, we also discovered that monsoon rains and increases in summer humidity have a significant influence on the frequency of late-summer wildfires within the macrosystem, and that this influence is independent from the longer-term influences of winter precipitation on forest wildfire cycles.

Overall, the research produced 21 publishable products and contributed as the primary funding source to the training of 12 post-doctoral associates and 6 graduate students.
